The film's honest portrayal of mental health and the complexities of teenage relationships make it a must see for anyone who has experienced the highs and lows of growing up. The film "The Perks of Being a Wallflower" is based on the same titled novel by Author and director Stephen Chbosky. It follows Charlie (Logan Lerman), a sixteen-year boy, through his first year of high school where he makes friends, finds love and grows up. There he befriends the Stepsiblings Sam (Emma Watson) and Patrick (Ezra Miller), with whom he spends the majority of his time. Charlie is a very self-conscious and inexperienced teenage boy with just a few friends. To change this, he decides to befriend Sam and Patrick, who gladly accept him into their circle of friends. With his new friend group, Charlie has his first experiences with alcohol, drugs, love, and a variety of other things. Over the time he develops feelings for Sam, but decides not to act on them, because their friendship is too important to him, and he sees Sam as more mature and experienced than he is.
What I like about the film is, how close to the reality, but also the novel it is. A lot of the scenes are directly adapted from the Novel, but I feel like a few very important things, that show Charlies character, are missing in the novel. For example, his "relationship" to Mr. Anderson (Paul Rudd). My favourite scene has to be of course the Tunnel scenes but I also really like, how the pictured the rocky horror picture show. 
Most of the characters are how I imagined them reading the novel, like Patrick or Sam. Although most characters were casted great, I think they could have done a better job casting Mary Elizabeth (Mae Whitman). I still loved the character, but the actress didn't fit the role in my opinion. 
In conclusion, I think the movie is really good, but after reading the novel it was a tiny bit disappointing. I still would recommend watching it, even though I would recommend reading the novel first, because it helps understand some of the scenes.

The Perks of Being a Wallflower is a superb film that made my heart race, sink, and laugh. It tends to be an accurate representation of the way of living of a great number of teenagers and adds to the relatability of this movie. The characters are really touching and very endearing. Released in October 2012 and directed by the author of the book it was inspired by : Stephen Chbosky, The Perks of Being a Wallflower stars Logan Lerman, in the main role of Charlie, Emma Watson, as Sam and Ezra Miller, as Patrick.
              Charlie, a sixteen-year-old teenager, is nervous about entering high school in his freshman year. After being discharged from a mental health care institution, he wonders if, with his shy and antisocial nature he is going to make some friends. That's his encounter with Patrick and his stepsister Sam, at a football game that is going to change his life.
              The main trio manages to capture the essence of teenage years while still showing the gap of two years between Charlie and the two seniors, more mature and experienced in a way. Lerman achieves to portray the mindset of a traumatised being and manages to move its audience in exposing and showing how his past impacts Charlie in his present. Patrick is well represented as a queer person; he is portrayed by Ezra Miller as a non-stereotypical gay and comes as a very touching character. His personality stands out when Miller falls in love and shows his love for his friends, which feels real and is outstandingly believable. Patrick is the comic element of this movie, but there is still a depth in his soul and a past in his life. The fact that we learn to know every character throughout the film is amazing because we learn their past, and their traumas, their lives. Sam is portrayed as a strong young woman by Emma Watson, struggling in her love life, and finding comfort in music and becoming really close to Charlie. Their love for each other feels so natural and it is nice to see movies in which characters really seem to love each other in the ways we would feel in real life.
              For the filming techniques, some scenes are really moving, touching, and filmed in such a way, that you feel like taking part of the movie. There is for example, towards the end of the movie just after Sam's departure, when Charlie questions himself and has a mental breakdown where he is tempted by the idea of suicide. This scene ruled by anxiety is interspersed with memories and traumas that aggravated his state and shows us how he became in such a state. There is also a lot of music throughout the whole movie, notably is the iconic scene in the tunnel, in which we understand that Sam enjoys feeling the wind on her skin, feeling more free and more infinite than ever.
              This movie conveys a message, first and foremost of love. But is also talks about serious topics like domestic and child abuse, the LGBTQ+ cause as well as just being accepted as who we are. Charlie is a wallflower, he is seen as only part of the decor and doesn't really mean anything, and Charlie has trouble fitting in socially, so he is a wallflower. But in the eyes of his friends, as Patrick once says in the movie : "You see things. And you understand. You are a wallflower", addressing Charlie. It conveys a message of acceptance and tolerance. They are delivered smoothly throughout the movie, making you cry and laugh, impacting you in such a way that it is impossible to feel indifferent about.
              As a teenager, it is hard to identify and not to feel lonely in the things we are experiencing. It is why we mostly rely on our friends, our age, who have a real impact on our lives as they understand what we feel and share our feelings. My evaluation of this film may be a little false because I have not lived that much trauma in my life but it truly gives off good vibrations in the end and could help more than one, feeling unsure about themselves and bad in their bodies. I truly recommend this stunning movie.

Perks of being a wallflower, a film directed by Stephen Chbosky in 2012 starring Emma Watson, Logan Lerman, and Ezra Miller is the coming of age movie. This film was perfectly designed, from the imagery to the actors' chemistry towards themselves and their roles. It speaks on many different levels of being a teenager, coping with death, loneliness, and the pressures and how hard trying to fit in can be. This film is truly refreshing in all aspects so much is not spoken about, but the images and scenes set up in this film provide the viewer with ‚Äòinsider' information that really keeps the viewer focused on the film. The director, Stephen Chbosky is also the author of the book version of this film, also he is the screenplay writer. The different themes are quite recongnizable and easy to catch on to: first love, drug use, homosexuality, sexual abuse and friendship. The film starts out with a freshly new freshman loner Charlie Kelmeckis (Logan Lerman) who actually carries the heavy weight of dark secrets. Luckily, unique and strong-minded seniors Sam (Emma Watson) and her homosexual stepbrother Patrick (Ezra Miller) take him under their wing and invites him to their friend group. Mary Elizabeth (Mae Whitman) developed feelings for Charlie and his laid back English teacher Mr. Anderson (Paul Rudd) spots great potential in his work and encourages him in the best ways. The screenplay in this film is by far one of the best I have seen, it takes you on a very emotional rollercoaster. One moment you find yourself caught in a dramatic scene, then a sad one, and then funny all within seconds. This film really highlights the true feelings and how introverts go through their thought process and all the perks of embracing being a wallflower. 
The imagery and acting in this film gives a strong sense of real life. The three leads perform so many memorable performances in the film that you can't help, but to feel the emotions that they are portraying. The topic of highschool kids struggles is very cliche, yet this film does such a great job at providing realism on how it was to be a highschooler in the late 80's/ early 90's and the struggle of offbeat kids who appear to be disengaged, but  still manage to find the positive side of this and have some fun even with all of the troubles with family, social conventions, and the discovery of one's sexuality during the painful adolescent phase that everyone can relate with because everyone has or will have to go through similar phases in their lives. 
The soundtrack to the film also helps captivate the emotions that are being shown in the film, it really helps bring the film together so you get a sort of ‚Äòvibe' for what each scene is kind of like just a presumption. This film also has some flashbacks of Charlie's past experiences which helps the viewer identify or get insight on what he went through in life and events that lead him to where he is at. The novel had a lot of buzz and was highly cherished when it was first released and some would argue that ‚Äòthe books are always better than the movie', however in this case there is no doubt that the statement is inaccurate in regards to this film. Both the novel and the film flatters each other in the best way. I personally think this is one of the best coming of age films to watch. Simply because the scenes are so intense and are very thought-provoking. Everyone fell in love with the film as they did the novel. I feel as though this is because it truly captures a little something for everyone, meaning that this film can connect people of all different kinds of backgrounds, races, and religions to its raw story. The film also has such a good group of supporting actors that help build the momentum throughout the whole movie. I feel as though with all the aspects shown in the film the imagery still has to be my favorite part of the film because it is personal and natural. Coming of age stories are centered around teenagers as they try to cope with the possibilities of life, even if these possibilities can be good or bad. Charlie has had a traumatic past, and throughout the movie, we know he suffers his fair share of demons which culminates in his anxiety and blackouts. We're led to assume that his mental health issues started because of his best friends suicide, but that was there to distract us from the truth and become unaware of the bombshells that the movie likes to set up for the audience member. And the writing also helps disguise this, with its focus on the main group of characters, which I'll call the Wallflowers.

The group dynamic of the Wallflowers was wonderfully executed and their interactions felt genuine. Their group had their highs, like the Christmas party, and their lows, like when Charlie broke up with Mary Elizabeth. Because of these highs and lows, the group was constantly changing and pushing the story forward with new plot threads such as Brad breaking up with Patrick after his dad discovered them in bed one night. Although we don't get as much character development on Mary Elizabeth and Alice, we get lots of character development for the others!

Really quick though, I need to address the absolutely stacked cast list this movie has. The directors did such a good job with casting these roles and I loved each person included. We got Logan Lerman, Emma Watson, Ezra Miller, and surprisingly Paul Rudd? His inclusion surprised me but it was a welcome surprise nonetheless. 

Let's start with Patrick (played by Ezra Miller). When we are first introduced to him, he is basically told by the workshop teacher that he is "Nothing", but Patrick doesn't even flinch and makes a snarky remark back at him. After this, everyone at school starts to call him nothing, which always sparks a similar reaction out of Patick. The only people that don't talk to him like this (that we see) are his sister Sam, the Wallflowers, and his secret boyfriend Brad. The first time we see him break his confident barrier is when Charlie finds Brad and Patrick in bed for the first time. Patrick is nervous about being outed makes Charlie promise to not say anything about what he saw. (Sidenote. I loved how the best friend actually kept a secret, and this wasn't used as a cheap tactic to cause drama between Brad and Patrick).

But this nervous breakdown was only the foreshadowing his character arcs climax, where Brad and Patrick break up in the school cafeteria. When Patrick tries to explain to Brad his feelings, Brad gaslights Patrick and denies everything he says so he doesn't get embarrassed in front of his friends. And the nail in the coffin hit right when Brad called him nothing. 

If I know anything, it is that harsh words hurt when it comes from someone you love. Just like Patrick, I can shrug off an insult from a random nobody on the street but what I can't shake is hearing that from someone close to me. So when Patrick finally punched Brad in the face, I bet that Patrick felt relief in that moment, letting go of his emotions all in a single punch to his stupid face. (If you can't tell, Patrick is my favorite character)

Looking closer at the story, all that Patrick wants is to be himself and accepted for who he is, but society keeps telling him he's nothing and that because he's gay there's something wrong about him. I'm glad that he has friends who accept him for who he is, and my heart goes out to the people who don't have the same support system as Patrick. I hope he finds love in due time.

Another favorite character is Charlie (played by Logan Lerman). The movie wastes no time establishing that Charlie is an outcast, that he's quiet, and that he is struggling to find his place in the world (which at this point is high school). I think the characterization of Charlie was wonderfully executed because these traits make him a relatable character for lots of people, especially those who are going through their own mental problems in their life. Not everyone is an outcast and not everyone is quiet, but I believe that everyone can relate to the struggle of finding their place in the world. When I watched this movie, I could relate to a lot of these things so I found myself really engaged with his character arc. Also he's a writer and I'm trying to get better at writing too so we have a similar goal in mind.

A piece of foreshadowing of Charlie's past with Aunt Helen, was when he was witnessing Ponytail Derek slapping his sister Candace (played by Nina Dobrev) in the face. He automatically went to defend his sister from Derek until Candace stopped him from coming into their room. I think that this was great foreshadowing for the eventual reveal that he was sexually abused by his aunt. I'd like to think that his motivation for protecting his sister wasn't only because they were siblings but rather because he didn't want her to go through the same thing. I wish we saw more of Candace, but her role in the story was pretty great, and I would assume it'd be hard to include lots of screentime to Candace since she wasn't a part of the Wallflowers. 

Something that surprised me about the story's execution of telling Charlie's story, was how it kept the causes of Charlie's anxiety a secret until the end of the movie. We have little indicators here and there that might suggest the true cause of why he ended up like this in the beginning of the movie, but nothing concrete until the end. And even by the end, the answers given to us are pretty vague and they leave a lot to our imagination. I believe the director decided that the movie had to keep the truth from the audience, just as Charlie was keeping the truth from everyone else. What the director wanted us to do was focus on how his anxiety and depression was affecting his life and relationships, showing audience members what their lives can be like.

Honestly, this character has a bunch of quirks that I could talk about in their own separate paragraph, but I think that this character works because of Logan Lerman's performance. All those little quirks wouldn't be there if he didn't pour his heart and soul into his performance.  And when your character is quiet by nature, the actor that plays this character needs to be able to tell the audience who they are, by using body expressions. So props to you Logan, you really did something great with this character. Now what about the third member of the main trio?

Sam (played by Emma Watson) was probably my least favorite character of the trio but I'm not saying that to make fun of the character. Sam doesn't really have a lot of character development to go through, so she plays the role of a mentor/guardian and love interest to Charlie. Seeing her in these roles are not surprising, but she still gives him advice even when she is dating another guy (I forgot his name sorry lol). But even when she wasn't even good friends with him, she helps Charlie from doing anything stupid and when her friends get Charlie high and she takes him upstairs to mellow out. Or when she learned that Charlie had no friends after his best friend committed suicide and made him a part of the wallflowers. 

So if you're wondering why a character with no big character development is in the story well I have to tell you that her character is absolutely crucial to the movie's success. First off, she is the glue that keeps the Wallflower's together, through a lot of their lows. For instance, she is the first to console Mary Elizabeth when Charlie kisses Sam in front of her, and she is the person to eventually invite Charlie back to the group after he saved Patrick from being to a pulp. 

The second thing is unrelated to the actual story, but I wanted to explain how her character affects pacing. Sam gives Charlie advice and consoles him multiple times, and if you stop to think about it, she is really the catalyst that starts Charlie's change as a person. If Sam was removed from the story entirely, the writer would have to create a new character to fit this mold so they can spark character development for Charlie. So while this isn't the most revolutionary character ever made, this character was perfect for the movie it was made for. Also Sam has a cool taste in music so that's pretty gnarly.

Speaking of music, this soundtrack SLAPS! This isn't just because they give us quality songs from the 80s (which is the best year of music, don't @ me), because these songs contribute to establish the time frame when this movie took place, which was some solid world building. Also the song Heroes by David Bowie, has always been a 10/10 song, but whenever it is used at the end of a movie or series to give it that last emotional moment, I will always have chills. 

So if you couldn't tell, I loved this movie. 10/10

Of course they may not have suffered sexual abuse as the main character here, but they may still develop serious mental problems from how other students treated them in high schools. Perks Of a Wallflower stars Logan Lerman as Charlie,  Emma Watson as Sam and Ezra Miller as Patrick. Based on the best selling novel by Stephen Chbosky, Perks of being a wallflower is about growing up, friends, love and loss. The coming of age story revolves around Charlie, a 15 year old boy struggling to find his place in life and high school until he meets Sam and Patrick befriend him and changes his life. 

Firstly, I want to talk about the themes shown in this film. Some were brilliant some were rushed especially towards the end of the film but for the most part they played out well. These themes included things like loneliness, heartbreak, friendships. During the start of the film the way they portrayed Charlie's loneliness worked very well and Logan made it a very real it felt somewhat relatable and you wanted to symphyse with him. We could also see depth into the characters that weren't quite there at first. For instance Sam had a troubled history and we can see how damaged she actually is inside and the way she acts come from. Although I liked those themes there were some that were terribly rushed, especially Charlie's mental breakdown I believe that could have been a great opportunity to dive into mental health but they missed it. I believe they should have focused on that more than his loneliness mainly because a lot of teen dramas focus on things like loneliness and it's getting quite repetitive. 

A part of the film I did love was the music. They hard some great music that complemented the film well for instants during the tunnel scene with Heroes by David Bowie or Come on Eileen. Music was also a big part of the film, they had old mixtapes, vinyls, talks about bands, good music vs bad. It was refreshing in a relatively new film having a soundtrack that was mostly based songs from the last few years. A big part of this film is that it seems very real and you weren't watching a film it seemed like you were there with them. The dialogue was great this way and could capture you instantly. The only part of the dialogue that didn't sit well for me was Sam's accent slipping from American to English at several points of the film. The best thing about this film is that it's not just a teenage film targeted to teenagers it's a film that can target anyone in some way.  For the adults I feel like they can look back on the film to get some nostalgia from the music and the new discoveries Charlie goes on. 

Overall it was a very good heartfelt film, that can relate in some way to everyone. I would highly recommend it. The story is good the subplots are great and the surprises were shocking. Really enjoyed it.

There are many ways to relieve pain. There are ways we know from what we see and experience -- the stories, the movies, the articles, the news, being the victim -- and there are the peaceful ways that are just as powerful: individual people who brings attention and awareness to mental illness, those are the people who changes the world. That is the kind of courageous resistance Stephen Chbosky show in Lionsgate Films 2012 film The Perks Of Being A Wallflower, rated PG-13. This film is about the story of a young teenage boy named Charlie, who has clinical depression due to childhood memories, is a movie everyone must see, so we can be inspired and strengthen the awareness for mental illness.
Ever since Charlie was little, his aunt has always been his favorite person until she passed away. He has never been mentally stable since but he tries to adapt the normal lifestyle of being a young high school student. Charlie is uneasy about beginning his freshman year because he has difficulty making friends and he's very shy. The only person he connected to at school was his english teacher, Mr. Anderson because he makes Charlie feel like he belongs in the school when Charlie feels like he doesn't belong anywhere. He meets two seniors, Sam and her step brother Patrick at a football game, they invite him to go out to eat and go to parties and such. At a party, Charlie eats a pot brownie and tells Sam about how his only friend committed suicide. On the way home, Patrick drives Sam and Charlie to a tunnel. They put on a song they've never heard of and Sam decides to go to the back of the pickup to enjoy the moment. That is when Charlie begins to fall for her. After realizing that Charlie is falling in love with Sam, he tries to find ways to show her that he cares about her and her happiness. At Christmas, Charlie reveals that he have never been kissed before. Although Sam is with someone else, she kisses him and tells him that she loves him. When Marie-Elizabeth asked Charlie to the Sadies dance, he tries not to hurt her feelings so he goes with her. That's when Marie-Elizabeth started falling for Charlie and somehow they began to date but keep in mind that Charlie is only dating her because he doesn't want to hurt her feelings but he gets more irritated with her as the relationship goes. At a party, Patrick asked Charlie to kiss the most beautiful person in the room and he kisses Sam unintentionally, hurting Marie-Elizabeth's feelings. Patrick recommends Charlie to stay away from them for awhile but Charlie starts having flashbacks of his aunt's death when he was seven years old. When Sam and Patrick goes away for college, Charlie experiences a flashback of his aunt's death and something else about his aunt that he wasn't sure about. He calls his sister and his sister realizes that he needs help so she calls for help. Charlie passes out and wakes up in a hospital. He then reveals to his doctor that his aunt has sexually abused him when he was little and that's what he has been scared of saying out loud for the longest time.
Frankly, I thought that this film is incredibly amazing. Chbosky really brought attention and awareness to mental health and why this issue is really important. Anything and anyone can really make you feel like you're trapped inside sometimes it's even yourself making you feel this way. I agree that people who supports others going through this, helps a lot. Everyone always needs someone to talk to and to make sure that they're okay. This movie has inspired me to bring more awareness to mental illness and help individuals who are going through this. Some people might not understand why mental health is as important as any other illnesses and this movie has many very important parts about mental illness since you get to see Charlie's point of view. Finally, I have to admit, this film is one of the best films I have ever seen. For example, one stereotype would be: she's only depressed so she could get attention. No, mental illness is a serious issue and no one should say anything like that because no one knows what she's going through. I recommend everyone to watch this movie. Not only will it raise awareness but it will put the audience in Charlie's shoes to show what he's going through and how much pain he has trying to fix himself.

Learning to grow up can be hard. The Perks Of Being A Wallflower, starring Emma Watson, Logan Lerman, and Nina Dobrev, captures the highs and lows of growing up. Charlie, a socially awkward teen in high school, has never really had any friends. When two older classmates take him under their wing his whole life changes. He takes part in his first party, first kiss, and first girlfriend, all while experiencing the trials of growing up and moving on. The movie hides nothing and bears all, captivating the audience with first hand not-so-magical high school stories, However, the plot can be a bit heavy at times.
